awd_titl_txt: Solving the Supernova Type Ia Progenitor Puzzle:  Building Bridges between Theory and Observation
awd_abstract_narration:
Supernovae (SNe), or the explosions of massive stars, are a critical component in measuring and understanding the accelerated expansion of the universe.  This is possible because astronomers are able to standardize a certain type of SNe (Type Ia) observed across the universe, due to similarities in their brightnesses.  However, there remain uncertainties in the standardization process, some of which stem from an incomplete understanding of the progenitors of Type Ia supernovae.  A research team led by the Smithsonian Institution Astrophysical Observatory will carry out a project to study the astrophysical systems within which the white dwarf stars that become Type Ia SNe are primed to explode.  The work will focus on the contribution of triple-star systems relative to binaries as SNe progenitors.  The results of this research will be of great interest to the general public, not only because of the fascination of Type Ia supernovae, but also because the work on three-star systems will produce eye-catching animations.  The researchers will work with science education experts to create planetarium shows whose subjects will be derived from the SNe research.  Research done through this program will become part of the narrative thread of a high school summer course the principal investigator teaches, and high school students, together with undergraduate students, will participate in the research. 

The objectives of the project are twofold. The researchers will (1) determine the contribution of triple-star systems relative to binaries, and (2) produce a cutting edge population synthesis code for public use, which employs state-of-the-art linkages between observations and evolutionary states, allowing diverse research groups to make meaningful comparisons of their results. To accomplish this, the scientists will conduct a systematic study of hierarchical triples in which the outer star contributes mass to an inner binary within a system that has the potential to form a Type Ia supernova.  They will also include three-body dynamics and will thoroughly explore the parameter space, focusing on detectable signatures. The dynamics will provide crucial input in the development of a new type of population synthesis code that includes binaries and triples, and will have the distinctive feature of built-in expandable links to existing and developing data sets from a variety of sources.   Better understanding SNe progenitors is especially important because wide-field surveys, including the NSF-sponsored Vera Rubin Observatory, are set to discover so many SNe per year that systematic uncertainties must be explored.  Other areas that benefit are the study of cosmic enrichment, necessary for the development of life, and improved predictions of gravity wave signals. Furthermore, the three-body problem is itself of great intellectual interest, and the work on mass transfer in triples will open new avenues of research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Type Ia supernovae are among the most powerful cosmic explosions. They occur when a white dwarf achieves a mass of about 1.4 solar masses.  Beyond their sheer power, Type Ia supernovae are amazing tools for cosmology. Because they are similar enough to each other to be called "standardizable candles", cosmologists can use them to measure the expansion rate of the Universe and even to  measure changes, accelerations, in the expansion rate.  Type Ia supernovae provided the first evidence that we live in an accelerating Universe. Universal acceleration has been interpreted as being due to an entirely new entity, dark energy. We now believe that dark energy dominates the energy budget of the universe.

As if this weren't enough, Type Ia supernovae are at the center of an ongoing cosmological puzzle. While they provide a good measure of the rate at which the universe expands, there are other methods that rely on studying processes that happened in the Universe when it was younger than the times at which Type Ia supernovae occurred. These large scale, early time methods appear to give a different rate of expansion. The apparent disagreement is referred to as the "Hubble tension".  It must be resolved if we are to truly understand the history and future of the Universe.

One major source of uncertainty is that we do not know which astronomical systems are the progenitors of Type Ia supernovae.  White dwarfs do not simply explode on their own. They are born with less than 1.4 solar masses. In fact the ones that explode are born with significantly less mass: most of their masses are significantly smaller than 1.1 times the mass of the Sun.  White dwarfs that explode as Type Ia supernovae must have started their lives as part of a binary or triple stellar system, or perhaps even a system with higher multiplicity.  There have been long-standing debates between those who favor different models. The uncertainty in the models is called the Type Ia progenitor puzzle.

The work we conducted under the aegis of NSF has allowed us to make two important steps toward the solution of the puzzle. The first step will allow theorists to make much better predictions of the rates at which each different model produces Type Ia supernovae.  The most challenging part of the calculations we must conduct to make predictions is to understand the effects of an entity referred to as the "common envelope".  When two stars in a binary or higher-order multiple come close enough to each that mass is stripped from one of the stars, the effects can be dramatic. If the donor star is more massive than its companion and/or if it is an evolved star, such as a giant, it can lose all of its stellar envelope - possibly several solar masses - in a matter of hours. The envelope surrounds both stars, becoming a common envelope.  This phase is so complex that reliable predictions of the post-common-envelope state of the binary are not only difficult, but different approaches can give wildly different answers. Our group tackled this problem and developed a formalism called the "SCATTER" formalism. SCATTER, which is based on both a sound theoretical principle and on comparison with a wide range of observed systems, represents a significant improvement over previous approaches. It also has the great advantage of being easily applied to triples and higher-order multiples. These latter may contribute significantly to the rate of Type Ia supernovae, but it has not, until now, been possible to consider them on a similar footing with binaries.

NSF funding also facilitated a serendipitous discovery that has important consequences for the solution of the Type Ia progenitor puzzle.  We discovered a new class of X-ray sources, hypersoft X-ray sources (HSSs), that may identify the progenitors in observations, long before explosion.  We know that, whether the pre-explosion white dwarf collects most of the matter it needs to explode from a companion, or through a merger with another white dwarf, it must pass through an epoch of high-rate mass accretion.  These fast-accreting white dwarfs should be among the brightest high-energy sources in galaxies, and they must emit high-energy photons.  Astronomers found a hint of the fast-accreting white dwarfs in a class of sources called supersoft X-ray sources (SSSs). But observations have found enough SSSs to definitively relate them to supernovae. We know, however, that some SSSs expand and become invisible in  X-rays, shifting their wavelengths to the extreme ultraviolet, where they become more difficult to detect. This is the regime that HSSs occupy.  In some galaxies we find more HSSs than SSSs, despite the fact that they are more easily hidden from our detectors. Thus, while the class of HSSs may include more than white dwarfs, HSSs may be the best candidates for the progenitors of Type Ia supernovae.
